title: Adorable baby elephant swimming with its trunk in the air resembles fabled Loch Ness monster
text:
Having had its existence once again called into question by scientists, it would not be surprising if the Loch Ness monster left its home in Scotland for a more welcoming environment.

And so it seemed when this dark shape emerged from a river in Africa, looking much like the creature in the famous, faked 1934 photo of Nessie.

But on closer inspection it turned out to be a baby elephant swimming with its trunk raised. It was snapped in Botswana’s Chobe River by wildlife photographer Dafna Ben Nun, 39, who found the resemblance to Nessie ‘very amusing’.

This dark shape emerged from Botswana’s Chobe River, looking much like the creature in the famous, faked 1934 photo of Nessie. But on closer inspection it turned out to be a baby elephant swimming with its trunk raised

Scientists from New Zealand said last month it was likely the ‘monster’ of Loch Ness was a giant eel.

Ms Ben Nun said: ‘I went over to Africa to photograph and learn about the wildlife there and I learned that this year is the driest year in the last 20 years so animals are in desperate need of water.

‘While photographing on the Chobe river I saw a group of elephants coming in to the river to cool down.

Scientists from New Zealand said last month it was likely the ‘monster’ of Loch Ness was a giant eel

‘They crossed the river while diving and splashing and most of the time just leaving their trunk above the water what resembled the Loch Ness monster to me.

‘It was very amusing and made me laugh.’

Professor Neil Gemmell, a geneticist from New Zealand’s University of Otago, said: ‘There is a very significant amount of eel DNA. The sheer quantity of the material says that we can’t discount the possibility that there may be giant eels in Loch Ness. Therefore we can’t discount the possibility that what people see and believe is the Loch Ness Monster might be a giant eel.’
description: A dark shape emerged from Botswana's Chobe River, looking much like the creature in the famous, faked 1934 photo of Nessie. But on closer inspection it turned out to be a baby elephant.
